articles.headline: Before Voting, Russian Leaders Go to the Polls
articles.snippet: In a political climate of personalities, the Kremlin keeps up on public opinion with a check of what segments of the population are thinking.
articles.abstract: In a political climate of personalities, the Kremlin keeps up on public opinion with a check of what segments of the population are thinking.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Every Thursday, a bearded, bespectacled man arrives at the Kremlin bearing a sheaf of data for Vladislav Y. Surkov, the government’s chief ideologist. There, a roomful of decision makers are gathered to hear the latest installment of What Russia Thinks.

articles.headline: A Bull Market in Tech Patents
articles.snippet: Recent blockbuster patent deals are fed largely by legal considerations, not economic ones, analysts say.
articles.abstract: Recent blockbuster patent deals are fed largely by legal considerations, not economic ones, analysts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google was willing on Monday to pay $12.5 billion for Motorola Mobility in no small part because of its stockpile of 17,000 patents. The patent portfolio, some analysts estimate, could represent more than half of the value of the deal, or more than $400,000 a patent.

articles.headline: Amazon Set to Publish Pop Author
articles.snippet: Amazon moved aggressively to fulfill its new ambition to publish books as well as sell them, announcing that it had signed Timothy Ferriss, the popular self-help guru.
articles.abstract: Amazon moved aggressively to fulfill its new ambition to publish books as well as sell them, announcing that it had signed Timothy Ferriss, the popular self-help guru.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon moved aggressively Tuesday to fulfill its new ambition to publish books as well as sell them, announcing that it had signed Timothy Ferriss, the wildly popular self-help guru for young men.

articles.headline: Pledge for Euro Unity May Not Be Enough to Satisfy Markets
articles.snippet: Leaders of France and Germany urged economic harmony for euro nations, but it was unclear if their plans would be enough to settle markets anxious over Europe’s debts and listless economies.
articles.abstract: Leaders of France and Germany urged economic harmony for euro nations, but it was unclear if their plans would be enough to settle markets anxious over Europe’s debts and listless economies.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The leaders of France and Germany on Tuesday promised to take concrete steps toward a closer political and economic union of the 17 countries that use the euro, but it was unclear whether their proposals would be sufficient, or come quickly enough, to satisfy markets anxious over Europe’s debts and listless economies.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: On Economy, Raw Data Gets a Grain of Salt
articles.snippet: Politicians and investors are placing a great deal of weight on a crude and rough estimate of economic growth that has never been particularly reliable.
articles.abstract: Politicians and investors are placing a great deal of weight on a crude and rough estimate of economic growth that has never been particularly reliable.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the government announced in April that the economy had grown at a moderate annual pace of 1.8 percent in the first quarter, politicians and investors saw evidence that the nation was continuing its recovery from the depths of the financial crisis. The White House called the news “encouraging” and the stock market extended its bull run.
